Is Da Vinciâ€™s masterpiece, the Mona Lisa, worth the hype?

By Emily Warner

Arts in York: what's on

A roundup of the interesting, the exciting, and the not-to-be-missed in York (Thumbnail credit Sebastian Faulk's Birdsong)

Review: Kevin Bridges

Tom Giles reviews stand-up comic Kevin Bridges' fantastic tour. (Thumbnail credit Kevin Bridges at York Grand Opera House)

Review: The Hot Mikado

By James Bithell

"The most fun you'll have in the theatre all year". This is a play that doesn't aim to take itself too seriously. Tom Giles Reviews.

Review: Calendar Girls

Tim Firth's heart-warming adaptation of the famous film Calendar Girls leaves a new found belief in humanity. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Lady Lovely Lute

The Open Drama Night has produced an intriguing and insightful documentary, in which intimacy and intelligence is brought to a girl's experiences of brain trauma. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

Calvitto offers an adaptation of Victor Hugo's dark tale, effectively bringing out Quasimodo's psychological affliction. Catriona Lacy reviews.

Review: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf

Joe Lichtenstein brings Edward Albee's contentious drama to life with enthralling results. Lily Grant reviews.

Review: An evening with Gary Lineker

An exploration of the role of football in society, 'An evening with Gary Lineker' sees an effective combination of subversive humour and accurate social commentary. Ben Cross reviews.

Review: Wild East

TFTV's latest offering 'Wild East' is a captivating piece which kept the intimate venue on tenterhooks throughout. Lucie Parker reviews. (Thumbnail credit (c)Wild East)

Happily Ever After Society presents: Little Shop of Horrors

Undeterred by a few loose screws here and there, Little Shop of Horrors is, as you would imagine, a fun and humourous production that HEA Soc can be proud of.

Best Book

JK Rowling's, A Casual Vacancy

Home is Where the Art is

Art is increasingly becoming more accessible for the Everyman, and Leeds Art Gallery is one of the most recent leaders in this movement

Illuminating York's Wonderland

Comedian Vic Reeves showcases his talent as an emerging artist as part of Illuminating York. Celia Scruby investigates (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Lily Grant)

The Comedians

With plot twists a-plenty, an unforeseen denouement, and a style of theatre entirely new to York, 'The Comedians' is a definite one to watch says James Metcalf.

In Pictures: Illuminating York

In Pictures: Illuminating York (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Lily Grant)

Review: Othello

With Othello being one of Shakespeare's most revered creations, the producer of York's latest interpretation of the play had the chance to do something new with it. Sadly, France's production did not take this opportunity, leaving reviewers Celia Scruby and Mary O'Connor wholly underwhelmed.

Paradise

Paradise left us wanting more as the play's central character, Ricky made us part of his story placing us as willing and eager voyeurs, says Lucie Parker.

Jack Dee Live

Jack Dee's dry humour and well-anticipated cynicism captivated the audience for the entirety of the performance, which, is no mean feat according to Alex Slingsby

Blue/Orange at Grand Opera House York

Blue/Orange seems to have a lasting effect on Nouse critics, as another York based production of the psychological drama leaves reviewer Sonali Dutta utterly mesmerised.

Review: Death Trap

Death trap is a play, that although is similar to a blockbuster thriller, ultimately should not be taken too seriously, says Celia Scruby.

The Guinea Pig Club

For a play with such emotional potential and immediacy, the sum performance fell just flat (Thumbnail credit Karl Andre Photography)

Editor's Picks

The Guinea Pig Club & African and contemporary dance in Leeds

Best Book: Merivel, A Man Of His Time by Rose Tremain

As always with Tremain, her new book is masterfully written. Merivel is a triumph, says James Metcalf.

The Naked Truth

As the celebrations of revolutionary artist Gustav Klimt are in full swing, Femke Gow takes a look at why he has become one of the most adored rebels of our time. (Thumbnail credit Klimt's last studio in Feldmuhlgasse, Vienna)

Flexing Her Lyrical Muscles

Tempest, whose lyrical ferocity has left the globe speechless talks to Mary O'Connor about being invisible and why all you need is love. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Battersea Arts Centre)

Hedda Gabler

A show that has left critics reeling, Hedda Gabler shocks and enthralls. (Thumbnail credit Hedda Gabler, played by Sheridan Smith)

http://www.nouse.co.uk/?p=63568

Thanks to Rose Tremain's masterful sequel to Restoration, the reputation of the sequel is on the rise, writes James Metcalf.

A Poetry Evening with Benjamin Zephaniah and Co.

Whilst initially disappointing that Kate Tempest couldn't appear, a triumvirate of terrific poets, Benjamin Zephaniah, John Berkavitch and Aoife Mannix made up for this tenfold with an evening full of witty and wondrous wordplay. (Thumbnail credit Benjamin Zephaniah)

Pounding his own path: the Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner

The temerity of both the adaptation and its lead actor were integral to the play's success in striking a chord with a modern audience.

POSH

Laura Wade's interpretation of Posh is masterful, encouraging us to interrogate the class consciousness that dominates our society, and the political institutions that underpin it.
